Himmelsbach | Cards nearly had 1st-half shutout

Louisville basketball jumped out to 29-0 lead over Savannah State

Himmelsbach | Cards nearly had 1st-half shutout

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 11:57 p.m. EST November 24, 2014

University of Louisville's Montrezl Harrell (24) dunks the basketball against Savannah State's defense during the second half of play at the KFC Yum! Center in Louisville, Kentucky, November 24, 2014.(Photo: John Sommers II, John Sommers II/Special to the CJ)

CONNECT 7 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Savannah State coach Horace Broadnax stood in the bowels of the KFC Yum! Center, smiled, and put this strange night in perspective. Sure, his team had started the 87-26 loss to Louisville by going nearly 16 minutes without a point. But there was nothing he could do about it now. So he smiled.

"I've got a beautiful wife with two kids that I can't wait to get back to," he said. "I'm gonna take a nice shower, drink me a cold beer, and move on."

And really, what else could you expect him to do after a night like this? Anger would be futile. Sadness would be unproductive.

"As a coach, I could have been in the locker room, kicking and threatening and all that crap," he said. "And then I lose the kids."

As he stood there, calm and collected, it was impossible not to feel for him and his team. They had never stopped playing hard. They did not sulk or complain to the referees. They did not openly blame each other. They did not start playing a dirty game.

They just kept trying to score. But that's where things became difficult.

RELATED: Louisville blanks Savannah State early, rolls 87-26

RELATED: Game Rewind | U of L rolls past Savannah State

RELATED: Instant Analysis | U of L routs Savannah State

On Sunday night, I watched Kentucky hold Montana State scoreless for a stretch of 13 minutes, 12 seconds. I don't think I've ever seen a drought that long, and figured it would be a while until I saw another one.

And then I took my seat at the KFC Yum! Center on Monday, and there was Savannah State.

It all started innocently enough. There were a few missed shots, a few turnovers, a few blocks. You looked up after five minutes and Louisville had an 8-0 lead. I said something to the people around me about how it would be crazy if there was another 13-minute scoring drought.

But of course there wouldn't be another 13-minute scoring drought. So we all settled in and waited for that first point.

And then we kept waiting. The shots kept missing. The turnovers kept coming. The 10-minute mark came and went. Then we passed the 13:12 mark from the UK/Montana State game.

Then we all started to wonder if the Tigers would score at all. Yes, that seems like an absurd notion, but if you were here, if you felt the rhythm of this half, you'd understand why it was a possibility.

"I thought we were gonna get a shutout," point guard Chris Jones said.

Louisville basketball coach Rick Pitino discusses the Savannah State blowout on Monday night at the KFC Yum! Center. Pitino said the team would not be reviewing the game film for the first time since he started coaching. Alton Strupp/CJ

Wayne Blackshear said that was the goal, not because the Cardinals are heartless, but because the objective on every possession is to stop the opponent from scoring. And when you do that over and over again, well, it gets ugly for the opponent.

Finally, improbably, with 4 minutes, 2 seconds left in the first half, Tigers forward Saadiq Muhammad drove through the lane and was fouled by Quentin Snider. At first glance, it looked like the foul had been committed on the floor, which would have resulted in an inbounds pass rather than free throws.

But the official called it a shooting foul, and there were some boos and some groans from the fans, who presumably figured they'd gotten this far, they might as well go for it. I haven't seen a replay, but if the official was showing some mercy, you can't really blame him.

Muhammad made the first free throw and missed the second, pulling his team within 29-1.

The Tigers' statistics leading up to their first point were jarring. They had missed 22 shots—five of which were blocked—and had had the ball stolen eight times. There was one shot-clock violation, one 10-second violation and plenty of discouragement.

U of L coach Rick Pitino was hardly chasing a shutout. Six minutes into the half, he had gone to a second unit that included Snider, Jaylen Johnson, Anton Gill and Mangok Mathiang. And later in the half, with the scoreless streak still intact, walk-ons Dylan Avare and David Levitch played.

"I don't like to see a team struggle like that," Pitino said. "I really don't."

A shutout would have been a curiosity, but it's for the best that it didn't happen. There is a fine line between a blowout and an embarrassment. Savannah State never stopped trying on this discouraging night, and it didn't deserve to be remembered for its misery.

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach
